questions.explanation:
> **Explanation**:
> Solutions found in Office 2019:
> File -> Open -> Recent -> Recover Unsaved Documents
> File -> Info -> Manage Document -> Recover Unsaved Documents
> Read carefully. It's not about recovering, but only the last recent file!
options: Click Open > Recent and select Recover Unsaved Documents.
Click File > Options > Recover Unsaved Documents.
Click File > Recent > Recover Unsaved Documents.

questions.explanation: > **Explanation:** The keyword here is creating a "shortcut" which is set with the Autocorrect Options by navigating to File -> Options -> Proofing -> AutoCorrect Options -> Replace text as you type.

What is the difference between a footnote and an endnote?

options: Footnotes use Arabic numerals and endnotes use letters.

questions.question:
You need to add a trademark symbol to a new product name. How can you accomplish this? (Select two items.)
A. Type "(TM)".
    B. On Windows: On the **Insert** tab, in the **Symbols** group, select **Symbol**. From the symbols gallery, select the trademark symbol, then   click **Insert**.
    On Mac: On the **Insert** tab, click **Advanced Symbol > Special Characters**, select **Trademark**, and click **Insert**.
    C. On the **Insert** Tab, in the **Illustrations** group, select **Icons**. From the icons gallery, select the **Signs and Symbols** category. Then select the trademark symbol and click **Insert**.
    D. Type "(R)".
questions.explanation:
**Hint:**
(TM) : Unregistered trademark symbol
(R): Registered trademark symbol

questions.question: You are reformatting a professional document that you created previously using manual formatting. In your document, first-level headings are formatted with Arial 11 Bold. What is the fastest way to create and apply a Heading 1 style using these properties?
questions.answer: On Windows: Select one of the first level headings. Right-click **Heading 1** and update it to match the selection.On Mac: With the **style** pane open, highlight a Heading 1 in the document, then in the style pane drop-down for Heading 11, select Update to Match Selection.
correctAnswer: On Windows: Select one of the first level headings. Right-click **Heading 1** and update it to match the selection.On Mac: With the **style** pane open, highlight a Heading 1 in the document, then in the style pane drop-down for Heading 11, select Update to Match Selection.
options: In the **Styles** task pane, click **New Style** and select **Arial 11 Bold**.
Hold the Ctrl key (Windows) or Command key (Mac) and click the **Format Painter**. Then select **New Style**.

On Windows: Select one of the first level headings. Right-click **Heading 1** and update it to match the selection.On Mac: With the **style** pane open, highlight a Heading 1 in the document, then in the style pane drop-down for Heading 11, select Update to Match Selection.
Select the text, right-click to display the formatting bar, and select **Styles > Copy**.

questions.question:

A. Colleague's name appears in the Share panel.

When you insert a picture into a document, what happens to the picture?
questions.answer: Word scales the image to the largest size possible to fit within the height or width of the page.
correctAnswer: Word scales the image to the largest size possible to fit within the height or width of the page.
options: Word stretches the photo to fill the page.
Word scales the image to the largest size possible to fit within the height or width of the page.

questions.question: When working with Track Changes, what is the difference between Simple Markup and all Markup?
questions.answer: Simple Markup shows the markup versions by one selected author; All Markup shows the combined markup version of all authors.
correctAnswer: Simple Markup shows the markup versions by one selected author; All Markup shows the combined markup version of all authors.
options: Simple Markup shows the final version without inline markups; All Markups shows the final version with inline markups.
Simple Markup shows the markup versions by one selected author; All Markup shows the combined markup version of all authors.
Simple Markup shows the revisions of one selected author in the Review pane; All Markup shows the revisions of all authors with inline markups.
Simple Markup shows the final version with inline markups; All Markup shows the final version without inline markups.

questions.question: You're finalizing a document that contains some high-resolution images. You want to reduce the picture size while ensuring image quality is adequate for online viewing. What is a best-practice approach?
questions.answer: Review the images and crop as needed. Then compress the images and delete cropped areas.
correctAnswer: Review the images and crop as needed. Then compress the images and delete cropped areas.
options: Review the images and crop as needed. Compress the images. Save the document and then compress the entire document.
Replace the images with lower-resolution images. Save the document and then compress it.
Review the images and crop as needed. Then compress the images and delete cropped areas.
Review the images and crop as needed. Save document and then compress it.

A pie chart only reads a single data series from a data source and ignores all others. You can determine which series is to be used by choosing Pie.

questions.question: You need to direct a reader from specific text to a related graphic that clarifies the content in another place in your document. Which command can you use to set this up?
When are mirrored margins typically used?
questions.answer: when printing on both sides of the paper
questions.explanation:
* Explain:
> Mirrored margins are commonly used when printing on both sides of a paper to ensure that the content is aligned correctly on each side. It helps maintain consistency and prevents any shift or misalignment when the paper is flipped to print on the other side.
correctAnswer: when printing on both sides of the paper
options: when printing on both sides of the paper
when the document has a header or a footer
when the text is formatted into multiple columns
when you need all the margins to be the same size

questions.question: You created a professional-looking business letter and would like to have all your letters look like this. What is the best way to do this?
questions.answer: Create a template by saving the file as a .dot file.
questions.explanation:
explain:
> 1. The best way to ensure that all your letters consistently have a professional-looking format is by creating a template.
> 2. By saving the file as a .dot (Word template) file, you can easily access it each time you need to write a new letter and start with the pre-defined formatting. This method allows you to maintain consistency and save time by not having to recreate the format manually for each new letter.
correctAnswer: Create a template by saving the file as a .dot file.
options: Save a copy of the file and type over it for each new letter.
Set the file as default theme.
Use the Format Painter to apply the format to new letters.
Create a template by saving the file as a .dot file.

questions.explanation:
* Explain
> Using the Version History feature, you can view and restore earlier versions of the document that were saved over time. It allows you to track the changes made to the document and revert back to a previous state if needed. This feature is helpful for recovering the document to a point before the unwanted changes were made.

questions.question:

questions.answer: Co-authoring with AutoSave enabled on cloud-stored documents
correctAnswer: Co-authoring with AutoSave enabled on cloud-stored documents
options: Co-authoring with AutoSave enabled on cloud-stored documents
File History rollback in version control

questions.question:
A researcher inserts 50 citations into a thesis using Microsoft Word’s “References” tab. Later, the citation style must change from APA to IEEE across the entire document.
How can this be done efficiently without reformatting each reference manually?
questions.answer: Changing the citation style in the References tab, which automatically reformats all in-text citations and the bibliography
correctAnswer: Changing the citation style in the References tab, which automatically reformats all in-text citations and the bibliography
options: Changing the citation style in the References tab, which automatically reformats all in-text citations and the bibliography
Using Find and Replace to manually edit citation formats
Re-inserting each source into the bibliography one by one
Exporting citations to Excel and importing them again in IEEE format

questions.question: In Microsoft Word, when working on a multi-section document, how can you apply different headers and footers for each section without affecting others?
questions.answer: Use Section Breaks and uncheck "Link to Previous" in the Header/Footer toolbar
correctAnswer: Use Section Breaks and uncheck "Link to Previous" in the Header/Footer toolbar
options: Use Section Breaks and uncheck "Link to Previous" in the Header/Footer toolbar
Change header/footer style from Design tab

questions.question: When creating a large technical report in Word, you want all figure and table captions to auto-update when new elements are added or reordered. Which feature ensures this consistency?
questions.answer: Insert Captions using the References → Insert Caption tool and use cross-references
correctAnswer: Insert Captions using the References → Insert Caption tool and use cross-references
options: Manually type captions below each figure
Insert Captions using the References → Insert Caption tool and use cross-references

questions.question: You are editing a legal document where every change must be visible, but some comments should remain private to reviewers. How can you achieve this?
questions.answer: Use “Track Changes” for edits and “Private Comments” in the Reviewing Pane with restricted permissions
correctAnswer: Use “Track Changes” for edits and “Private Comments” in the Reviewing Pane with restricted permissions
options: Use “Track Changes” for edits and “Private Comments” in the Reviewing Pane with restricted permissions
Save the document as a PDF to hide edits

questions.question: When working with a Word document connected to an external data source (like Excel), what allows dynamic updates of embedded data without re-importing?
You’ve created a company report in Word with multiple authors editing different parts simultaneously. To merge their edits efficiently without version conflicts, which method is most effective?
questions.answer: Use “Compare and Combine Documents” feature under Review tab
correctAnswer: Use “Compare and Combine Documents” feature under Review tab
options: Use “Compare and Combine Documents” feature under Review tab
Enable Autosave in OneDrive and overwrite versions
Use Comments and manually merge files
